ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about reputation, time consistency, and oligopolies. Learned a lot about complex game theory models and proofs. Became much more comfortable with reading papers. Understanding reputations and oligopolies in the papers not be directly applicable to anything but such analysis helped me apply game theory to other phenomena (hair cuts, grades, etc)
How to read Econ papers, present model, results and provide intuition. Write literature review for a broad Game theory topic.

I did not develop any knowledge on anything game theory related because it went by way too fast. The class is set up so every week we go over a research paper on dynamic games that takes hours to read because they are so difficult to understand. If you have zero experience or knowledge on game theory I highly discourage you to take this class.

How game theory works, what Nash Equilibrium is and how to find it. All about repeated games, with a focus on literature in collusion, reputation, and time consistency. How to read, understand and evaluate a variety of game theoretic models and proofs.
Firstly, I learned a lot about dynamic games. Moreover, I practiced my skills of essay writing and presentation.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Much of the course is student presentations. Would've been helpful to have some analysis from the teacher at the end of each topic. Another problem set would've been nice to help us demonstrate or apply what we'd learned

Strength: Professor is so kind and smart, the contents are very useful
Weakness: intensive math and the introductory lectures can be more

The strength is that its semi interesting if you can understand what you are reading. The weakness is that the Professor does not teach anything, every week a student presentation occurs and you are expected to take notes and at the end, understand what the paper is saying. But the problem is that almost all the students dont know what they are really presenting on and the Professor has to come in and explain the rest of the presentation because nobody understand what they are saying.it could be improved by having the Professor actually teach and explain the papers without having to interrupt students because they are not properly explaining the paper. There was a lot of time wasted in this class by having the students try to explain the papers in their own words.
Highly organized course. Very interesting papers assigned as reading each week. Assignments fun and manageable. But felt like slightly too much time during classes was spent on student presentations.
I think the workload can be larger to encourage students to pay more effort.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would definitely recommend the course. The work wasn't that bad but I definitely learned a lot. Anna is a very chill but very insightful teacher. When you are not presenting (which was once a semester) you only have like twenty pages of reading a week with no checks on whether or not you read

Game theory is super interesting and is applicable to all decision making. This course just introduces you to new game theory thought
Yes. It is a pre PhD course to help us know what it is like to do research.
I would recommend this course to all seniors.

If you understand game theory really well, and I mean really well...then I may recommend you take this class because it introduces a lot of interesting and new topics in game theory. If you have never taken a class on game theory, I highly recommend you NOT to take this class.

Yes! It was a fascinating deep dive into game theory, which I had never learned before, with assignments (presentation, critical evaluation/literature review of papers) that help internalise the material.
Yes, if the student is interested in dynamic games.
